prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Underpass Echo

Twas in the gloom of Slabbert's span,
Where Whirly-echo played its plan,
The sound did chirp an empty can,
Beware the echoing man.

For Drip-drop pebble he took his stand,
With Clackety-clack in either hand,
With Scramble-crump to banish fear,
Brave Thronmo met the sphere.

Quick quick through the Wibble-wall,
He faced the echo's thrumming call,
With Zizzle-bang from wall to wall,
He silenced the echo's thrall.

Back through the Slabbert's span he flew,
With Hoo-rah and Yahoo-boo,
The Clackety-clack grew bright and true,
He'd tamed the echo-view.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title "The Underpass Echo" present on its own line before stanzas.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 4 stanzas, each with 4 lines, meeting stanza count and line count criteria.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines show some length alternation but less consistent strong ballad meter; about 2/4 stanzas show clearer alternation.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme scheme generally ABAB or ABCB with slant rhymes and no dominance of AABB; lines 2 and 4 mostly rhyme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>No clear ring composition or repeated content words/phrases echoing the first stanza in final stanza beyond "Slabbert's span".</C5_think>
<C6_think>First stanza includes warning phrase "Beware the echoing man".</C6_think>
<C7_think>Second stanza shows protagonist preparing with "Drip-drop pebble he took his stand, With Clackety-clack in either hand".</C7_think>
<C8_think>Third stanza describes encounter "He faced the echo's thrumming call".</C8_think>
<C9_think>Third stanza shows decisive 'silencing' of echo with "He silenced the echo's thrall".</C9_think>
<C10_think>Fourth stanza implies return/celebration "Back through the Slabbert's span he flew, With Hoo-rah and Yahoo-boo".</C10_think>
<C11_think>At least 8 distinct coinages: Slabbert's, Whirly-echo, Drip-drop, Clackety-clack, Scramble-crump, Thronmo, Zizzle-bang, echo-view, Hoo-rah, Yahoo-boo.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coined word or phrase, well spread.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature/entity "Thronmo" is likely the protagonist, but adversary is an echoing presence, no non-canonical adversary creature named except maybe "echoing man", more like adversary concept than distinct entity.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia appears with "Drip-drop", "Clackety-clack", "Zizzle-bang", "Hoo-rah", "Yahoo-boo"; more than 2 onomatopoeic bursts present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance apparent in "Whirly-echo played its plan", "Clackety-clack", "Scramble-crump", and "thrumming call"; at least 2 stanzas show deliberate alliteration/consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is playful with whimsical invented words and lively sounds fitting a mythic, fanciful feel rather than prose or flat tone.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines exactly match the canonical poem, no verbatim reuse detected.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens limited to "Twas" only; canonical lexicon usage minimal, well under 8 distinct canonical tokens.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Long lines mostly 8–9 syllables, shorter lines about 5–7; alternating cadence roughly held in majority of stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme pairs vary well across stanzas, no exact repetition of rhyme end words more than twice.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word is overused excessively; lexical repetition within safe limits.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show diversity in roots and forms; no single coined suffix/root dominates over 50%.</C22_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Mists of Morgensthrum

The foggy fields did wisp and whirl,
Where misty wraiths did huff and puff,
The Clear-Eyed spoke with warning curl,
"The Fog-Runner must wake up!"

He grabbed his thistledrum bright,
With glimmerglade to guide his way,
Through shadows deep and dimmed light,
He sniffed and slinked at break of day.

A slash! A crack! The Shadow-Bane struck,
Through mornwist thick and morning dew,
The Mist-Wraith fell, by fortune luck,
And cleared the path for me and you.

With hum and huzzah! He returned,
The Sun-Singer sang with joyful sound,
Through paths where wispages burned,
Triumphant on misty ground.

The foggy fields still wisp and whirl,
Where misty wraiths may huff and puff,
The Clear-Eyed speaks that warning curl,
"Fog-Runners must always wake up!"
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Mists of Morgensthrum" is non-empty and before the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 5 stanzas; 4 lines each, so all stanzas have 4 lines, and total stanza count is 5, within 3–8.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer (≈8-9 syllables) and shorter (≈5-7 syllables) fairly consistently in 4 out of 5 stanzas; cadence matches ballad rhythm.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme for 4 stanzas; rhyme scheme mostly ABAB or ABCB; no AABB dominance evident.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening stanza with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases ("foggy fields," "wisp and whirl," "mists," "warning"); clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early warning present in stanza 2 via Clear-Eyed speaking a warning about the "Fog-Runner" needing to wake up.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist’s preparation shown in stanza 3: he "grabbed his thistledrum bright" and uses "glimmerglade" to guide, plus "sniffed and slinked," indicating plan/readiness.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter in stanza 4 with the "Shadow-Bane" striking and the "Mist-Wraith" falling; a confrontation with adversary/obstacle evident.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive killing/slaying act: "Mist-Wraith fell, by fortune luck," the path cleared; central tension resolved.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 5 with "Sun-Singer sang with joyful sound" and triumphant tone, indicating jubilant acknowledgment.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct invented coinages: Morgensthrum, wisp, whirl (common?), wraiths, thistledrum, glimmerglade, mornwist, wispages, huzzah (common exclamation?), Shadow-Bane, Mist-Wraith, Sun-Singer; clearly ≥8 distinct coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or invented compound word or novel term.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creatures: "Shadow-Bane," "Mist-Wraith," "Sun-Singer," and "Clear-Eyed" (perhaps an entity or a figure giving warning); Mist-Wraith is central to the action. Not canonical creatures.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "A slash! A crack!" in stanza 4, "hum and huzzah!" in stanza 5; at least two onomatopoeic bursts present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance clear in multiple stanzas: "wisp and whirl," "misty wraiths," "sniffed and slinked," "paths where wispages burned," showing deliberate sound patterning.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is mythic and playful, with whimsical coined terms and lively cadence matching Jabberwocky style.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim from Jabberwocky; all lines original wording with new content.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens (like "mimsy," "borogoves," "tumtum," "snicker-snack") are absent or very minimal; canonical words used are generic ("The," "and") not from canonical list. So ≤8 canonical tokens?</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness matches pattern in ≥60% stanzas; longer lines ~8-9 syllables, shorter lines ~5-7 syllables, consistent with Jabberwocky ballad meter.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme in lines 2 and 4 varies across stanzas; rhymes do not repeat excessive times; good variety.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word is repeated excessively outside ring echo; different coined words used each stanza and low repetition rate.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show diverse roots: thistledrum, glimmerglade, Shadow-Bane, Mist-Wraith, Sun-Singer, wispages, mornwist—at least 5+ distinct roots; no single suffix dominates.</C22_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Shadow-that-Remembers

Beware the Frumphant, my son!
The eyes that gleam! The mind that hesitates!
Beware the Echo-wraith, and run
From fate that anticipates!

He took his zyndor blade so bright:
Long had the recurring visions sought—
So rested by the Quivering Tree,
In thoughtful thought.

And, as in pensive thought he stood,
The Mindbender, with gaze of frost,
Came whirling through the misty wood,
And bubbled as it crossed!

Slice! Whack! Thrust! The zyndor blade went
SPLOOSH! CRACK! WHAP!
He left it vanishing, with its dread
He went tripping back.

"Hast thou conquered the Mindbender?
Come to my arms, my knowing son!
O glorious day! Hooray! Hurrah!"
He sang with fun.

Beware the Frumphant, my son!
The eyes that gleam! The mind that hesitates!
Beware the Echo-wraith, and run
From fate that anticipates!
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title present before first stanza: "The Shadow-that-Remembers" is present and non-empty.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 7 stanzas total; 6 stanzas have 4 lines, except the 5th stanza which has 5 lines. 6/7 = ~86% four-line stanzas; total stanza count within 3–8 range with one deviation allowed.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer/shorter pattern mostly upheld; e.g. first stanza shows a mix of lengths with shorter and longer alternating lines; similarly in other stanzas, at least 60% follow the alternating length pattern with noticeable content word differences.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme scheme is mostly ABAB/ABCB ballad style: e.g. first stanza rhyme "son"/"run" (B rhyme) and "hesitates"/"anticipates" (A rhyme). Lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme in ≥60% of stanzas without AABB dominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats the opening stanza verbatim, echoing ≥2 content words ("Beware the Frumphant, my son!…") and a clear refrain structure.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: first stanza begins with "Beware the Frumphant, my son!" explicitly warning protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist prepares: in 3rd stanza he "took his zyndor blade," "rested by the Quivering Tree," and "stood in thoughtful thought," indicating preparation and resolve before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter: the "Mindbender" appears in stanza 4, described with active movement "came whirling…bubbled," indicating confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying action evident in stanza 5: onomatopoeic bursts ("Slice! Whack! Thrust!", "SPLOOSH! CRACK! WHAP!") and "He left it vanishing," indicating resolution of conflict.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration present: stanza 6 contains celebratory language “O glorious day! Hooray! Hurrah!” and affectionate return "Come to my arms, my knowing son!"</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages: "Frumphant," "Echo-wraith," "zyndor," "Quivering Tree" (partial coinage name), "Mindbender," "bubbled" here used in nonce lively sense (though canonical "burbled" avoided), onomatopoeic bursts are words like "SPLOOSH," "WHAP," plus alliteration. At least 8 distinct non-canonical coinages across the poem.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage word, e.g., "Frumphant" (1), "Echo-wraith" (1), "zyndor" (3), "Quivering Tree" (3), "Mindbender" (4), onomatopoeic bursts or coined sounds in 5th stanza, celebration words in 6th, reflections in last stanza same as first.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical named creatures other than the Jabberwock: "Frumphant," "Echo-wraith," "Mindbender" mentioned and central to tale; "Mindbender" is the direct adversary slain.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "Slice! Whack! Thrust!" and "SPLOOSH! CRACK! WHAP!" are clear onomatopoeic bursts, more than 2 total in stanza 5.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: multiple stanzas have clear alliteration, e.g. stanza 1 "mind that hesitates," stanza 4 "whirling through the misty wood," stanza 5 “Slice! Whack! Thrust!”; thus ≥2 stanzas satisfy this.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is whimsical and mythic with coinages, a heroic arc, and playful language like "O glorious day! Hooray! Hurrah!"</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines are verbatim from canonical Jabberwocky; the final stanza repeats opening but is not the canonical opening lines, so no verbatim canon lines.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens like "beware" appear (common English word), no canonical nonsense words used; canonical distinct tokens ≤8 (actually zero canonical nonsense tokens). Mostly new coinages.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts roughly fit ballad tightness: longer lines mostly 8–9 syllables, shorter lines 5–7, e.g. stanza 1 line 1 "Beware the Frumphant, my son!" (6 syllables), line 2 "The eyes that gleam! The mind that hesitates!" (9+ syllables), alternating rhythm preserved in majority stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme varied across stanzas with no overuse of exact end words for (2,4) rhyme beyond the ring echo stanza.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word outside ring echo repeated overly; "son" repeated multiples times but within acceptable limits; coinages vary; no overused word dominates.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages have at least 4 distinct roots: "Frumphant," "Echo-wraith," "zyndor," "Mindbender," "Quivering" (adjective but also a coinage word used as proper name), so variety >4 distinct roots.</C22_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
# The Trample-Tale

Through grassy-gloom where trail-things creep,  
Beware the Pathfang with tweet-tweet,  
His slither-steps go slip-slide-round,  
On meadow-grounds he surely hounds!  

With trip-toes shod and clip-clamp chain,  
I practiced my path-straining vein,  
On hush-hush moss with pit-pat sound,  
To meet the beast with boundless bound!  

One slash! My feet went zing-zing free!  
Two jumps! The grass did scream with glee!  
I snicker-snacked through weed-we-wild,  
The Pathfang's strength grew mild and mild!  
With whiffling blade I struck the beast,  
His trail-tread now would cease to feast!  

O frabjous day! O callooh callay!  
I danced then through the green array,  
With crunch-crunch sounds of victory,  
My way laid out for all to see.  
Through grassy-gloom where trail-things creep,  
My secret path I safely keep.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "# The Trample-Tale" present before first stanza, non-empty and separate from stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 5 stanzas total; stanza 3 has 6 lines, others mostly 4 lines, so >70% (4/5) have 4 lines and stanza count is within 3–8 with one deviation allowed.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer/shorter with noticeable syllable difference in ≥3 of 5 stanzas; the 3rd stanza is longer but cadence mostly alternating; overall cadence consistent with Jabberwocky’s lively alternating pattern.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Most stanzas rhyme end lines (2 and 4), with some slant rhymes (e.g., "creep"/"tweet-tweet", "sound"/"bound") and do not show AABB dominance; variety in rhyme scheme is maintained.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza partially repeats opening line’s content ("Through grassy-gloom where trail-things creep"), producing a ring echo with ≥2 repeated content words ("grassy-gloom", "trail-things", "creep").</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition is present in the first stanza (“Beware the Pathfang with tweet-tweet”), an explicit warning to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation shown in stanza 2: “With trip-toes shod and clip-clamp chain, I practiced my path-straining vein,” indicating readiness and practice before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear meeting/confrontation shown in stanza 3 with direct action and mention of beast (“I snicker-snacked…The Pathfang’s strength grew mild”).</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action evident: “With whiffling blade I struck the beast, His trail-tread now would cease to feast!” resolving conflict.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration by stanza 4: “O frabjous day! O callooh callay! I danced then through the green array,” jubilation after victory.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: “grassy-gloom,” “trail-things,” “Pathfang,” “tweet-tweet,” “slither-steps,” “trip-toes,” “clip-clamp,” “path-straining,” “snicker-snacked” (used as coinage), “whiffling” (canonical but minor), “weed-we-wild,” “trail-tread” (possible coinage), “crunch-crunch.” More than 8 distinct invented coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or more (e.g., "tweet-tweet", "clip-clamp", "snicker-snacked", "crunch-crunch").</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature “Pathfang” is a non-canonical named entity central to the action.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia present: “tweet-tweet,” “pit-pat,” “snicker-snacked,” “crunch-crunch,” “zing-zing,” “clip-clamp.” At least two strong onomatopoeic bursts occur.</C14_think>
<C15_think>At least two stanzas have clear alliteration or consonance: stanza 1 “trail-things” and “tweet-tweet,” stanza 2 “trip-toes shod and clip-clamp chain,” stanza 3 “weed-we-wild,” stanza 4 “crunch-crunch sounds.”</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tonal alignment is playful and mythic with whimsical creations and lively action, well capturing Carroll’s poem’s spirit.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines exactly match canonical poem; wording is original with coinages and rephrased structure.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical words limited to “O frabjous day! O callooh callay!” and “whiffling,” only a few canonical tokens, total ≤8; usage favors new coinages.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Most stanzas show syllable count close to Jabberwocky’s ~8/6 pattern on alternating lines, though stanza 3 is longer, overall meets threshold ≥60% stanzas with proper syllable tightness.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme words at lines 2 and 4 vary across stanzas; no end word reused more than twice besides allowed echo; rhyme variety preserved.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word is overused excessively outside ring echo; coinages and normal words spaced appropriately without repetition beyond limits.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages derive from multiple distinct roots: “grassy-,” “trail-,” “Path-,” “tweet-,” “slither-,” “trip-,” “clip-,” “path-,” “weed-,” “crunch-,” “snicker-” etc., showing >4 root variety; no single suffix dominates.</C22_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Boardroom Berserk

'Twas urgent in the conference dome,
The slates began to squirm and blinker.
The议题Widgets made their home
Where digital thoughts grow whirler.

"Prepare now!" cried the Clackernome
With thumbs quick and clicky-clack.
The Glitch-beasts gathered, grinding, groan -
The zig-zag data crack-splash-flack!

Click, swipe! Flick, flounce! Through chart and text,
The Laser-Pen went zizz-and-zap!
He struck them down, complex quite vexed,
The PowerPoints stopped their rap and flap.

"And have you slain the Clackernome?
Come with your prize, clever boy!
O Data-rich day! Sync-and-stow!"
He high-fived crew with deploy.

And urgents bloom in Conference-Dome,
He battled on through digital night.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Boardroom Berserk" is non-empty, before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Five stanzas total; four stanzas have 4 lines, last has 3 (just one deviation); stanza count is within 3–8. ≥70% stanzas are quatrains.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer/shorter roughly in most stanzas, e.g. "Click, swipe..." (short) followed by "The Laser-Pen went zizz-and-zap!" (longer) with 2+ content word difference; overall cadence consistent in ≈60% stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme is mostly ABAB or ABCB ballad rhyme, (lines 2 and 4) rhyme held in ≥3 stanzas; slant rhymes accepted; no strong AABB overdominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza echoes "Conference-Dome" from the opening, repeating "urgent"/"urgents" and location element; at least 2 repeated content words ("Conference-Dome", "urgents") present, giving mild ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Explicit admonition: “Prepare now!” cried the Clackernome" acts as a warning/preparation call, but no direct "Beware" style caution in early parody stanza; warning implicit in stanza 2.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist prepares with "Laser-Pen," and the line "Prepare now!" suggests readiness and tool selection before battle.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter: Glitch-beasts described as adversaries; "He struck them down" indicates confrontation with named creatures.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act: "He struck them down," "The PowerPoints stopped their rap and flap," describes slaying or neutralizing the threat.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: "Come with your prize, clever boy! ... He high-fived crew..." suggests triumphant return and jubilation.</C10_think>
